metadata.title: Bioactive mesoporous nano-silica/potato starch films against molds commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Food Hydrocolloids
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/foodhyd
Bioactive mesoporous nano-silica/potato starch films against molds commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms
Rongfei Zhang, Meng Cheng, Xiangyou Wang∗, Juan Wang Department of Food Science and Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, 255000, Shandong, , China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Cinnamon essential oil Mesoporous silica nanoparticle Film Antibacterial property
A B S T R A C T
Cinnamon essential oil (CEO) was successfully loaded into mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs). To protect and preserve post-harvest white mushrooms (Agaricus bisporus) from CNRMA 03.0371 strain (Mucor circinelloides) and FJ09 species (Mucor sp.), MSNP-CEO/potato starch films were prepared by a casting method to develop a functional packaging design. The cooperation of MSNPs-CEO markedly enhanced the tensile strength and physical properties of films. MSNPs-CEO appeared to be more evenly distributed in the films by scanning electron microscopy analysis. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed that inter-molecular interactions were formed between MSNPs-CEO and potato starch. In addition, the in vitro release rate of CEO in the MSNPs from the films was investigated to improve its antimicrobial activity against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms stored at 4 °C. The MSNP-CEO/ potato starch films showed better antimicrobial activity against FJ09 species than against CNRMA 03.0371 strain.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Plastic packaging materials are practically neither biodegradable nor biocompatible (Verma, Vinoda, Papireddy, & Gowda, 2016). Therefore, several recent studies have focused on the design of biodegradable films, and biopolymers, such as starch, have been used (Zhou, Ren, & Li, 2017). In addition, microbial contamination can shorten the shelf-life of food and cause severe foodborne illnesses (Wen et al., 2016), so the active packaging can be used to delay or inhibit the decay of food and extend its shelf-life (Stanzione et al., 2017). However, starch films have poor properties, including inferior mechanical properties, low strength, unsatisfactory water resistance (Hu, Jia, Zhi, Jin, & Miao, 2019) and poor antimicrobial activity, so they are not suitable for the preservation of food.
For these reasons, the reinforcement of films by nanomaterials was investigated (Ghanbarzadeh, Oleyaei, & Almasi, 2015; Souza & Fernando, 2016). Several nano-oxide particles, such as nano-SiO2, nano-TiO2 and nano-ZnO, have been used as potential nanocomposite materials (Ahmadizadegan, 2017; Akhavan, Khoylou, & Ataeivarjovi, 2017; Sun, Wu, Hao, Dai, & Li, 2016). These nano-oxide particles were dispersed into the biopolymer matrix to alter the seepage path of the water molecules in the films. Among the nano-oxide particles, nanosilica exhibits the greatest potential due to its high surface activity and exceptional porous structure. Therefore, nano-silica films can maintain
the quality and extend the shelf life of food (Shi et al., 2013; Song et al., 2016). The nano-SiO2 was dispersed evenly in the potato starch films, which changed the micropore structure of the potato starch films so that the Si–O–Si groups in the films could control the exchange of O2 and CO2. In addition, the nano-SiO2 could change the permeation path of H2O2, O2 and CO2, which inhibited the respiration and weight loss of fruits, and avoided the lipid oxidation of food (Zhang, Wang, Li, Cheng, & Zhang, 2019). Previously, we reported that nano-SiO2 with a diameter of 100 nm was well dispersed in the starch matrix and enhanced the performance of films. However, these films showed poor antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus (Zhang, Wang,& Cheng, 2018).
Mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs) with their unique properties have been widely used in the field of biotechnology (Dong et al., 2015). MSNPs allow the loading of large amounts of active substances due to the large surface area of their highly ordered pores, which enables them toeffectively capture and release these substances (Balaure et al., 2017). A number of components of plant essential oils (EOs), such as carvacrol, carvone, cinnamaldehyde, citral, p-cymene, eugenol, limonene, menthol, thymol, etc., are generally recognized as safe (GRAS) by the United States Food and Drug Administration (cite: 21CFR582.20) (Burt, 2004). The EU already accepted at least one EO as additive on the “Everything Added to Food in the US” (EAFUS) list. EOs possesses powerful antimicrobial activity against a variety of foodborne

pathogens (Aumeeruddy-Elalfi, Gurib-Fakim, & Mahomoodally, 2016). Cinnamon essential oil (CEO) was selected, because it displays antibacterial activity against many common microorganisms. For example, Zhang, Liu, Wang, Jiang, and Quek (2016) reported that CEO exhibited an effective antibacterial activity against foodborne spoilage caused by Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. Shen et al. (2015) tested the effect of cinnamaldehyde on the cell walls of E. coli and S. aureus and demonstrated that cinnamaldehyde at a concentration of 0.31mg/mL damaged the integrity and permeability of the cell walls. Another study showed that cinnamon, oregano and thyme EOs in marinades extended the shelf-life of fish and meat products (Van Haute, Raes, Der Meeren, & Sampers, 2016). The incorporation of CEOs into biopolymer films may not only enhance their antimicrobial properties but also reduce their gas permeability and avoid their lipid oxidation (Hafsa et al., 2016). Souza, Goto, Mainardi, Coelho, and Tadini (2013) reported that CEO/ cassava starch composite films showed strong antimicrobial activity against Penicillium commune and Eurotium amstelodami, which were fungi commonly found in bread products. Moreover, micro-emulsions of cinnamon bark oil and soybean oil enhanced the transparency of chitosan films, but more importantly, their microbiological safety (Ma et al., 2016). Other studies reported that CEOs enhanced the physicochemical properties and the antimicrobial activities of biopolymers films (Noshirvani et al., 2017; Ojagh, Rezaei, Razavi, & Hosseini, 2010), although CEO is not very stable becauseof its high hydrophobicity and volatility. The release of CEO from the films affected its antimicrobial activity, which was revealed after bioactive mesoporous silica nanostructures were tested against clinically relevant microbial species (Balaure et al., 2017). Another study reported that vanillin release from amino-functionalized mesoporous silica was reduced during the production of polymer films (Stanzione et al., 2017). In this context, we aimed to develop a mesoporous silica-based delivery system (MSNPsCEO) where the release of the active compound was controlled by specific pore interactions. This system could be used to assign antimicrobial activity to films, which might meet the requirements for a new generation of packaging.
In the present work, an active packaging system (MSNPs-CEO) was developed using potato starch films. The main goal was to prepare bioactive MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films and to investigate the effect of MSNPs-CEO on the microstructural, mechanical (tensile strength) and physical (water vapor transmission rate, oxygen transmission rate, thermal stability, water solubility and moisture absorption) properties of the films. The MSNP-CEO/potato starch films were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The slow release of CEO from the films was investigated by UV–Vis spectroscopy. Moreover, the disk diffusion method was used to test the antimicrobial activity of CEO against molds, namely, the Mucor circinelloides CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the Mucor sp. FJ09 species, which are commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms (Agaricus bisporus) stored at 4 °C. Therefore, the MSNP-CEO would powerfully enhance the antimicrobial efficacy of essential oil or improve the dispersibility of nanoparticles in the films. The MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films are potentially useful in the food packaging industry.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Potato starch with a moisture content of 20% and a pH of 4.5–7.0 was purchased from Beijing Aoboxing Bio-tech Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), and ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). Cinnamon essential oil (density: 1.034 g/cm3, boiling point: 246.8 °C at 760mmHg; soluble in alcohol) was purchased from Guoguang Co., Ltd. (Jilin, China). White
mushrooms (Agaricus bisporus) were purchased in Zhangdian, Shandong, China. The uniform characteristics (size, shape, and color) of white mushrooms were selected to perform the package test.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO
sections.text:
Mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs) were prepared as previously described (Balaure et al., 2017; Kalbasi & Mosaddegh, 2011). CTAB (4.8 g), analytical-grade ethanol (100mL), and aqueous ammonia (24mL) were added to 100mL of deionized water. After the solution was stirred for 10min, TEOS (6.8 g) was added dropwise, and then the solution was stirred for an additional 2 h at 25 °C. The solid particles were filtered from the solution, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100 °C. To remove the template, the sample underwent calcination treatment at 550 °C for 6 h.
To prepare MSNPs-CEO (Balaure et al., 2017), 200mg of MSNPs was combined with 200 μL of CEO and 2mL of chloroform in a 10-mL plastic centrifuge tube. The mixture was sonicated to homogeneity using a VCX 750 ultrasonic processor (Sonics & Materials, Newtown, CT, USA) at a power of 150W and a frequency of 20 kHz for 20min. The solvent was completely evaporated at ambient temperature. This step was repeated three times.

sections.heading: 2.3. The inhibitory concentration of MSNPs-CEO
sections.text:
The CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species are commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms stored at 4 °C. These two molds were isolated and identified as shown in Fig. 1. The inhibitory concentration of CEO against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species was determined using the agar well diffusion method (Gupta, Dubey, & Kumar, 2016; Nalawade, Bhat, Suma, & Nikhil, 2016). An agar medium (PDA) plate was evenly coated with 50 μL of the spore suspension (105 cells/mL) with an applicator. A hole (diameter, 4 mm; depth, 2 mm) was created in the center of the plate using a sterile metal perforator and sealed at the bottom with a drop of agar solution. Subsequently, a 30-μL aliquot of MSNP-CEO at the indicated concentration (0.002, 0.004, 0.006, 0.008 or 0.010 g/mL) was added to each hole, and the plate was incubated at 28 °C for 48 h. The inhibitory zone was observed after incubation. Each test was performed in triplicate.
2.4. Preparation of the films
The potato starch films (S0), MSNPs/potato starch films (S1) and MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films (S2) were prepared as shown in Supplementary Figure s1. Prior to the preparation of MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO, 0.6 g MSNP-CEO and 0.6 g MSNPs were mixed with 100mL of distilled water. The suspensions were sonicated to homogeneity using an ultrasonic processor for 20min. Subsequently, potato starch (5 g/100mL of water) and glycerin (5 g/100mL of water) were dissolved in a water bath at 80 °C for 30min, and 100mL of the mixture was poured into a plastic culture dish (length, 25 cm; width, 25 cm). The films were dried at 50 °C in a circulation oven. The dried films were removed from the plastic culture dish and conditioned in a chamber (BSC-150, manufacturer name, city, China) (temperature, 23 °C; relative humidity 50%) for 48 h prior to the characterization and measurement of their properties.
2.5. Characterization of films and MSNPs-CEO

sections.heading: 2.5.1. SEM and TEM
sections.text: The morphology of the films was observed using a FEI Sirion 200 scanning electron microscope (FEI, Hillsboro, OR, USA) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Cross-sections of the films were coated with a thin layer of gold on a cylindrical stub. The morphology of the MSNPs was observed using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN HR-transmission electron microscope (FEI Company) at a working voltage of 200 kV.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. 2FTIR
sections.text: The FTIR spectra of MSNPs, MSNPs-CEO, pure potato films, MSNPs/ potato films and MSNPs-CEO/potato films were analyzed using a Nicolet 5700 Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The samples were scanned at wavelengths in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 at a spectral resolution of 2 cm−1 after they were dried at 23 °C for 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.5.3. XRD
sections.text: The X-ray patterns of films were scanned between 2θ=5° and 50° using a D8 Advance XRD apparatus (Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation at a voltage of 40 kV and 30mA.

sections.heading: 2.5.4. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and derivative thermogravimetry (DTG)
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analyses of MSNPs, MSNPs-CEO, pure potato films, MSNPs/potato films and MSNP-CEO/potato films were carried out using a Netzsch STA449C thermogravimetric analyzer (Freistaat Bayern, Germany). High-purity nitrogen was used as the carrier gas, and the samples were programmed from 30 to 600 °C at an increment of 10 °C/min.
2.6. Mechanical and physical properties of the films
The water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of the films was determined gravimetrically, according to ASTM method E96-95. In brief, anhydrous CaCl2 (3 g) was placed into a glass cup (height, 30mm; diameter, 50 mm). The cup was sealed and conditioned at a temperature of 23 °C and a relative humidity of 90% for 24 h.

The thickness of the films was determined using a digital micrometer (Hangzhou United Bridge Tools Co., Ltd., Hangzhou, China) with a precision of 0.01mm. Each film was measured in at least 10 random locations. The oxygen transmission rate (OTR) was determined according to the Chinese National Standard of GB/T 1038–2000 (Wang et al. (2014). The OTR was measured by a gas permeability tester (VACV1, Labthink Instruments, Jinan, China). The changes in the pressure indicated the oxygen transmission.
The tensile strength (TS) and elongation at break (EB) of films (2 cm×5 cm) were determined using a TMS-2000 texture analyzer (Food Tech Corp., Sterling, VA, USA). The initial separation distance was 30mm and the velocity was 10mm/s.
2.7. In vitro release of CEO from the films
CEO solutions at various concentrations (0.001, 0.002, 0.003, 0.004 and 0.005 μL/mL) were prepared and measured using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 281 nm to generate the standard curve. The CEO loading content was calculated using the standard curve. The release of CEO from the films was performed as previously described (Matshetshe, Parani, Manki, & Oluwafemi, 2018; Keawchaoon & Yoksan, 2011; Hosseini, Zandi, Rezaei, & Farahmandghavi, 2013) with minor modifications. The MSNP-CEO/ potato starch films were incubated at various temperatures (4, 20 and 40 °C) and relative humidities (40, 60 and 80%). A phosphate-buffered solution (PBS, pH=6.5) was mixed with anhydrous ethanol at a 3:2 ratio (v/v). At 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, and 12 days after synthesis, segments of the films were obtained and extracted with the PBS-ethanol solution at 15000 rpm for 5min at 25 °C. The supernatant was used to determine the CEO concentration using an UV–Vis spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 281 nm. Each sample was analyzed in triplicate. 2.8. Antibacterial property of the films
The antibacterial characteristics were examined using the disk diffusion method (Vimala et al., 2011). Briefly, 6mm disk-shaped films were seeded on agar plates containing the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species, and the plates were incubated for 48 h at 28 °C. The diameters of the zones of inhibition around the films were examined to determine the antibacterial characteristics of CNRMA 03.0371 and FJ09 strains.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sections.text: The variance of all data was analyzed using SPSS software (ver. 20). Tukey's post-hoc comparison test was used to identify significant differences. P-values< 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sections.heading: 3.1. The inhibitory concentration of MSNP-CEO
sections.text:
The CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species were obtained after the mushrooms were stored for 7 days at 4 °C (Fig. 1). The commercial value of white mushrooms infected with CNRMA 03.0371 and FJ09 strains was reduced due to a shortened shelf-life. The inhibitory concentration of MSNP-CEO against CNRMA 03.0371 and FJ09 strains are shown in Fig. 2 and Supplementary Table s1. The results showed that the MSNP-CEO exerted antibacterial effects on the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species. Among these two molds, the sensitivities to the CEO were different, and the susceptibility of the FJ09 species was excellent with the lowest MIC. The antimicrobial activity of MSNPs-CEO against the FJ09 species was very obvious in all series of concentration. However, the minimum inhibitory concentration value of the MSNPs-CEO against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain was 6mg/mL, which was chose to prepare the films in this study. The MSNPs-CEO was more effective against the FJ09 species than against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain, showing a higher inhibition with lower concentration. Balaure et al. (2017) also found that the minimum inhibitory concentration differed depending on the microbial species and the type of the essential oils used. Therefore, MSNPs-CEO of with 6mg/
mL concentration was chosen to be incorporated into the potato starch films.

sections.heading: 3.2. SEM and TEM analysis
sections.text:
The mesopores of MSNPs were investigated using TEM. The TEM micrographs (Fig. 3a and b) showed that the MSNPs possessed a highly ordered mesoporous structures that was capable of loading the CEO. The microstructure of the food preservation films would determine their physicochemical properties and their food preservation
performances. The dispersion of nanoparticles in the films played a crucial role in improving the food preservation properties of the films (Sun et al., 2016). Fig. 3c–h presented the cross-sections morphology of the films. The potato starch films exhibited a smooth and flat cross section, while the MSNPs/potato starch films presented the serious particles aggregation and coarse cross sections. Remarkably, the MSNPs-CEO was uniformly dispersed in the films which may have occurred due to the decrease of –OH groups in the surface of MSNPs and the value of the specific surface area of MSNPs decreased with the loading of CEO. Mesoporous silica nanoparticles had a tendency to form aggregates, as also found by Balaure et al. (2017). Yang, Shi, and Xia (2018) and Sun et al. (2016) also reported that the nano-SiO2 in the films was prone to particle agglomeration, affecting the properties of the films. The excellent bone structure and high stiffness of the MSNPsCEO could relieve serious particles aggregation in the potato starch films to enhance the properties of films.

sections.heading: 3.3. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
FTIR was employed to analyze chemical bond structures of MSNPsCEO and the intermolecular interaction of materials. The FTIR of MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO were shown in Fig. 4a. The MSNPs revealed the characteristic bands for O–H stretching vibration (3443 cm−1), Si–O stretching vibration and Si–OH stretching vibration (1087-961 cm−1) (Tabatabaei, Jafari, Mirzaei, Nafchi, & Dehnad, 2018; Xu, Zhang, Zhao, & Zou, 2017). However, the absorption bands of MSNPs-CEO were different from those of MSNPs in most cases. Especially, the O–H stretching vibration MSNPs-CEO became weakened, which indicated that the MSNPs-CEO could be well dispersed in the potato films. The stretching vibrations in the range of 1682–1480 cm−1 were ascribed to the carbonyl double bond C¼O characteristic of CEO, and the absorption bands at 750 cm−1 and 690 cm−1 due to the aliphatic and aromatic C–H bonds (Balaure et al., 2017). It demonstrated that the CEO was successfully entrapped into silica networks.
The FT-IR spectra of the films (Fig. 4b) indicated that there was a similar pattern, and that no chemical bond was created between materials in the films. However, the frequency intensity of the peaks about some functional groups leaded to a shift in the different films. The intense and broad absorption peak between 3400 cm−1 and 3500 cm−1 was attributed to stretching vibration of –OH (Yu, Li, Chu, & Zhang, 2017). The O–H stretching vibrations of the films with MSNPs and the films with MSNPs-CEO were located at 3318 cm−1 and 3335 cm−1, respectively, due to the strong interaction among the O–H groups of potato starch, MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO. For the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films, asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes for –CH2- and –CH– were shifted to 2860 cm−1 meanwhile the intensity of the bands was decreased. It indicated that the hydrogen bonds formed between potato starch and MSNPs/MSNPs-CEO enhanced the tensile strength
properties of films (Abdel Aziz, Salama, & Sabaa, 2018; Wang et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 3.4. XRD analysis
sections.text: The XRD patterns of MSNPs, MSNPs-CEO and various films are depicted in Fig. 5. The broad peak at 2θ of 20° was assigned to amorphous MSNPs, which is consistent with the results of Fernandezbats, Pierro, Villalongasantana, Garciaalmendarez, & Porta, 2018. The XRD pattern of MSNPs-CEO (Fig. 5a) exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 9.94, 18.5, 22.94, 25.52 and 29.66°, which confirmed the formation of MSNPs-CEO. For the films, after the addition of MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO, the diffraction intensity of the main crystalline plane of potato starch films decreased. The crystallinity degree of pure potato starch was about 63%, while the crystallinity degree of MSNPs/potato starch films and MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films were about 56% and 47%, respectively. Owing to the interactions among MSNPs, CEO and potato starch molecules, the arrangement regularity and the native crystalline domains were destroyed. Meanwhile, it should be clearly noted that the crystalline peaks of MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films at 9.67, 18.25, 22.89, 25.32 and 29.54° were observed in Fig. 5b. This change might result from the formation of strong interactions between potato starch molecules and MSNPs-CEO, namely by hydrogen bonds and electrostatic interactions. This behavior was similar to that described by Matshetshe et al., 2018.

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermal analysis
sections.text:
TGA and DTG were used to estimate the amount of CEO that interacts with the MSNP and investigate the thermal stability of films. To this purpose, the loading capacity of MSNP-CEO was calculated according to the TGA curves in Fig. 6a. The weight loss of almost 70% was observed in the MSNPs-CEO, indicating that a mass of CEO was loaded in the nanopores of MNSPs. For the films, two main weight loss steps were observed in the curves in Fig. 6a. The first step (105–200 °C) was ascribed to the evaporation of loosely bound water and CEO in the films. The second step (260–310 °C) was owing to the decomposition of polymer matrix (Yang et al., 2018). The DTG curves (Fig. 6b) of the films showed that the MSNP-CEO/potato starch films exhibited a large weight loss rate (11.5 °C/min) during the first stage, resulting in the volatilization of CEO. From 260 °C to 310 °C, all the films started to pyrolysis while the decomposition rate of MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films was faster. Meanwhile, the decomposition temperature of MSNPsCEO/potato starch films needed higher. It indicated that the MSNPsCEO could be uniformly distributed in the films, in which the hydrogen bonds were formed between potato starch and MSNPs or MSNPs-CEO, and the interaction among the polymer chains was intensified. The results were in agreement with the SEM. In general, the thermal
stability of the potato starch film increased after blending with the MSNPs-CEO.
3.6. Physical and mechanical properties of the films
Film thickness was not significantly (p > 0.05) affected by the addition of MSNPs and MSNPs-CEO, as shown in Table 1. The qualities of food in the package were connected with the transfer of water and gas from the inner and outer packing materials (Crizel et al., 2018), which reduced the WVTR and OTR and played an important role in the films application. As shown in Table 1, the WVTR and OTR of the films decreased due to interactions with MSNPs and CEO. It was clearly observed that the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films were superior to the other films in retarding water and gas transfer. The lower WVTR (644.41 g d−1·m−2) and OTR (4.86 g d−1·m−2) were ascribed to the hydrogen-bond interaction between MSNPs-CEO and potato starch which could reduce the diffusion of moisture and gas in the films. Moreover, the more evenly dispersed MSNPs-CEO changed the micropore structure of the films, consistent with the SEM results.
As shown in Table 1, the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films had a significantly higher tensile strength and a lower elongation at break compared to other films (p < 0.05). The tensile strength and elongation at break of films were determined by the molecular structure of the polymers. Other researchers also found that increasing TS and decreasing EB of nano-films were ascribed to interfacial interactions between nano-particle and polymer (Hassannia-Kolaee, Khodaiyan, Pourahmad, & Shahabighahfarrokhi, 2016). The MSNPs-CEO was more evenly distributed in the film matrix and more strongly bonded with potato starch, and therefore, the interphase adhesion strength between MSNPs-CEO and the matrix was enhanced (Colivet & Carvalho, 2017). Additionally, the formation of hydrogen bonds improved the
mechanical properties of the films which increased the mobility of the chains in the amorphous region of the films (Hassannia-Kolaee et al., 2016). The TS and EB of films was negatively affected by the nanoparticle aggregation and local stress (Shahabighahfarrokhi, Khodaiyan, Mousavi, & Yousefi, 2015; Li et al., 2011).
3.7. The in vitro release rate of CEO from the films
The in vitro release rate of CEO from the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films was investigated at various temperatures and relative humidities for 12 d. As shown in Fig. 7a, a standard curve of CEO at a wavelength of 281 nm was drawn to determine the retention of CEO in the films and calculated the cumulative release percentage of CEO. The CEO release from the films took place by several mechanisms, including the diffusion of CEO from the MSNPs into the films and the degradation of the potato starch films matrix (Hosseini et al., 2013). The release kinetics of lemon essential oil microencapsulated using mesquite gum-Chia mucilage mixtures was investigated by Cortés-Camargo et al. (2019), which further demonstrated the aforementioned release mechanisms. The cumulative release percentage of CEO at the commonly stored temperatures for fruits and vegetables of 4 °C, 25 °C, and 37 °C was illustrated in Fig. 7b. There were two stages of the CEO release pattern curves, including an initial burst and then a very slow CEO release (Hariharan et al., 2006). For the first 6d, the initial burst release of CEO occurred with release percents of 73.22%, 78.30% and 89.49% at 4 °C, 25 °C and 37 °C, respectively. The release of CEO at this stage was attributed to CEO adsorbed on surface of MSNPs(Anitha et al., 2011). After 6 d, the cumulative release percentage of CEO slightly increased due to the diffusion of CEO in the micropore of MSNPs (Hosseini et al., 2013). In addition, the release rate of CEO from the films increased with the rise of temperature, which might be due to the faster volatilization
of CEO. A similar behavior was observed by Matshetshe et al. (2018). The cumulative release percentage of CEO at different relative humidities (40, 60 and 80%) increased with the rise of relative humidities. The CEO in the films exhibited a higher release rate at a relative humidity of 80% in Fig. 7c. Therefore, more CEO could be released at the high relative humidity of 80%. These results suggested that the MSNPsCEO/potato starch films could be a potential approach to control the diffusion of CEO and inhibit the growth of molds commonly found in postharvest white mushrooms stored at 4 °C.
3.8. Antimicrobial property of films
The CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species infected the white mushrooms during storage, which caused the mushrooms to putrefy and decompose, thereby shortening the shelf-life of the mushrooms. To evaluate the potential antimicrobial activity of the films, the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species were tested by the agar disk diffusion method. Fig. 8 shows the antimicrobial effects of the MSNPsCEO/potato starch films in comparison with the pure potato starch films and MSNPs/potato starch films. Obviously, the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films exhibited a good antimicrobial activity against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species, whereas very little antimicrobial activity was displayed by the other films. Additionally, MSNP-CEO/potato starch films had a better antimicrobial activity
against the FJ09 species than the CNRMA 03.0371 strain,which was demonstrated by the size of the inhibitory zone.
The antimicrobial effect of the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films may be mainly ascribed to the CEO in the MSNPs. Some researchers (Ojagh et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2016) proved that the principal components of CEO were ketones, aldehydes, phenolic and the trans-cinnamaldehyde or cinnamaldehyde was the major active component of CEO (Wen et al., 2016). The active components of CEO could attack the phospholipid cell membrane, disrupt enzyme systems, disrupt the balance of inorganic ions and pH in the cytoplasm, and damage proteins and lipids (Hafsa et al., 2016). Therefore, the different antimicrobial activity of the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species might reflect the differences of the cell structures between the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species. Further insight studies into all the possible mechanisms of the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species will be required. On one hand, the cell wall and membrane lysis of molds might be caused by a physical damage or chemical reaction during the action of CEO. On the other hand, the specific approach in which CEO entered into the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species is unknown. Moreover, CEO may have an effect on the genetic material of the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species. These themes will be further investigated.
The values are presented as means ± SD. Different letters within the same column indicate significant differences (p < 0.05).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this study, CEO was embedded into the mesopore of MSNPs and adsorbed on the surface of MSNPs to develop a functional packaging design. The WVTR, OTR and TS of potato starch films were markedly enhanced by the incorporation of MSNPs-CEO. Furthermore, the thermal stability of the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films was superior to that of the other films, as shown by the analysis of TG and DTG curves. SEM showed that MSNPs-CEO was more evenly distributed throughout the potato starch films, avoiding the aggregation of MSNPs. FTIR and XRD showed that inter-molecular interactions were formed between MSNPs-CEO and potato starch. In addition, the in vitro release rate of CEO from the MSNPs increased with the rise of temperature and relative humidity. Remarkably, the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films showed better antimicrobial activity against the FJ09 species than against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain. Further studies are needed to define the antibacterial mechanism of the MSNPs-CEO/potato starch films against molds. This newly developed method with MSNPs-CEO holds potential in the development of active packaging designs for the preservation of food.

MSNPs allow the loading of large amounts of active substances due to the large surface area of their highly ordered pores, which enables them toeffectively capture and release these substances (Balaure et al., 2017).
The incorporation of CEOs into biopolymer films may not only enhance their antimicrobial properties but also reduce their gas permeability and avoid their lipid oxidation (Hafsa et al., 2016).
Moreover, micro-emulsions of cinnamon bark oil and soybean oil enhanced the transparency of chitosan films, but more importantly, their microbiological safety (Ma et al., 2016).

Other studies reported that CEOs enhanced the physicochemical properties and the antimicrobial activities of biopolymers films (Noshirvani et al., 2017; Ojagh, Rezaei, Razavi, & Hosseini, 2010), although CEO is not very stable becauseof its high hydrophobicity and volatility.

The release of CEO from the films affected its antimicrobial activity, which was revealed after bioactive mesoporous silica nanostructures were tested against clinically relevant microbial species (Balaure et al., 2017).
Another study reported that vanillin release from amino-functionalized mesoporous silica was reduced during the production of polymer films (Stanzione et al., 2017).
Mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs) were prepared as previously described (Balaure et al., 2017; Kalbasi & Mosaddegh, 2011).
To prepare MSNPs-CEO (Balaure et al., 2017), 200mg of MSNPs was combined with 200 μL of CEO and 2mL of chloroform in a 10-mL plastic centrifuge tube.
The antibacterial characteristics were examined using the disk diffusion method (Vimala et al., 2011).
The dispersion of nanoparticles in the films played a crucial role in improving the food preservation properties of the films (Sun et al., 2016).

The stretching vibrations in the range of 1682–1480 cm were ascribed to the carbonyl double bond C1⁄4O characteristic of CEO, and the absorption bands at 750 cm and 690 cm due to the aliphatic and aromatic C–H bonds (Balaure et al., 2017).
It indicated that the hydrogen bonds formed between potato starch and MSNPs/MSNPs-CEO enhanced the tensile strength properties of films (Abdel Aziz, Salama, & Sabaa, 2018; Wang et al., 2018).
The second step (260–310 °C) was owing to the decomposition of polymer matrix (Yang et al., 2018).

The qualities of food in the package were connected with the transfer of water and gas from the inner and outer packing materials (Crizel et al., 2018), which reduced the WVTR and OTR and played an important role in the films application.

Additionally, the formation of hydrogen bonds improved the mechanical properties of the films which increased the mobility of the chains in the amorphous region of the films (Hassannia-Kolaee et al., 2016).
The TS and EB of films was negatively affected by the nanoparticle aggregation and local stress (Shahabighahfarrokhi, Khodaiyan, Mousavi, & Yousefi, 2015; Li et al., 2011).

The CEO release from the films took place by several mechanisms, including the diffusion of CEO from the MSNPs into the films and the degradation of the potato starch films matrix (Hosseini et al., 2013).
There were two stages of the CEO release pattern curves, including an initial burst and then a very slow CEO release (Hariharan et al., 2006).
The release of CEO at this stage was attributed to CEO adsorbed on surface of MSNPs(Anitha et al., 2011).
After 6 d, the cumulative release percentage of CEO slightly increased due to the diffusion of CEO in the micropore of MSNPs (Hosseini et al., 2013).

metadata.abstractText: Cinnamon essential oil (CEO) was successfully loaded into mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNPs). To protect and preserve post-harvest white mushrooms (Agaricus bisporus) from CNRMA 03.0371 strain (Mucor circinelloides) and FJ09 species (Mucor sp.), MSNP-CEO/potato starch films were prepared by a casting method to develop a functional packaging design. The cooperation of MSNPs-CEO markedly enhanced the tensile strength and physical properties of films. MSNPs-CEO appeared to be more evenly distributed in the films by scanning electron microscopy analysis. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed that inter-molecular interactions were formed between MSNPs-CEO and potato starch. In addition, the in vitro release rate of CEO in the MSNPs from the films was investigated to improve its antimicrobial activity against the CNRMA 03.0371 strain and the FJ09 species commonly found in post-harvest white mushrooms stored at 4 °C. The MSNP-CEO/ potato starch films showed better antimicrobial activity against FJ09 species than against CNRMA 03.0371
